Dear Ms. Hargis:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
8/8/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for each
licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section citation,
e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be implemented
and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that
each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of seven employee files reviewed (three long term and four under one year) did
not have the required annual verification of a TB test. The last TB test for this
employee occurred on 5/4/21 with this inspection taking place on 7/28/22.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
This facility is non-contracted with Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services therefore, MISEP requirements are not applicable.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. This facility is non-contracted with Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services, therefore, MDHHS Policy/MDHHS contract are not
applicable.

 The facility now has a compliance officer and we discussed a tracking form

 No consultation was provided or requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
4

The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment or corporal punishment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan was in response to the 2021 Interim Licensing
Inspection. Four violations were found, and the facility submitted an approved CAP
(8/4/21) for each. For the violation of missing information on the discharge plan, the
facility was to train all staff involved in the writing of the discharge plan. Each
discharge plan was also to be reviewed within 5 days of discharge by the compliance
officer. During this inspection, the compliance officer provided documentation that he
has completed this task and no violations were found within the discharge plans. The
next three violations all involved different aspects of facility and premises
maintenance. The first being damaged screens on windows that open, corroded
shower heads in the bathrooms, and one of the two bathrooms having loose flooring
titles. The CAP for these issues involved the development of a “maintenance check
list” which overnight staff are to complete. This was documented as being completed
and during this inspection, the repairs were observed to have been completed.
The second corrective action plan was in response to the special investigation
2022C0328003 with an approved CAP on 1/18/22. This special investigation involved
additional findings that the facility failed to report a youth AWOL, as required, to the
licensing authority. The CAP for this finding involved the facility retraining all staff on
the procedure to be taken when a youth is AWOL The social services supervisor will
follow up within 12 hours to ensure that the correct action was taken with an AWOL
youth, and this will be documented in a case note. A follow up case note will also
confirm that all appropriate written action has taken place.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
This report outlined the efforts and progress the facility made on the before
mentioned corrective action plans. There were significant details to the efforts made
and the addition of a “Compliance Officer” was noted. This new position has helped
with the compliance of their files. The facility identified the need to hire an outside
training agency to provide more comprehensive and up to date training to staff. Pay
raises have occurred and the facility continued to improve their “onboarding” process.
Interviews:
There were no youth present in the program at the time of this inspection. It was
reported the last youth in the program had left several days prior. Staff interviewed
were able to report the additional training and focus on AWOL youth. All understood
the procedure to follow. Staff reported feeling very supported by the administration
and believe they are providing a positive and healthy service to youth. Administration
interviewed reported the positive changes that have been occurring due to the CAPs
and present with a “best practice” focus.
5

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that
the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
